The answer is guaranteed to fit in a 32-bit integer. ç¤ºä¾‹1ï¼š Input: s = â€œ12â€ Output: 2 Explanation: It could be decoded as â€œABâ€ (1 2) or â€œLâ€ (12). ç¤ºä¾‹2ï¼š Input: s = â€œ226â€ Output: 3 Explanation: It could be decoded as â€œBZâ€ (2 26), â€œVFâ€ (22 6), or â€œBBFâ€ (2 2 6). ç¤ºä¾‹3ï¼š Input: s = â€œ0â€ Output: 0 Explanation: There is no character that is mapped to a number starting with â€˜0â€™. We cannot ignore a zero when we face it while decoding. So, each â€˜0â€™ should be part of â€œ10â€ â€”> â€˜Jâ€™ or â€œ20â€ â€”> â€˜Tâ€™. ç¤ºä¾‹4ï¼š Input: s = â€œ1â€ Output: 1 æ³¨ï¼š <= s.length <= 100 s contains only digits and may contain leading zero(s). å…¥é—¨çº§çš„dp+åˆ†æ²»ã€‚ä½†è¿™æ–¹é¢çš„é¢˜æˆ‘åšçš„ç¡®å®ä¸å¤ªå¤šâ€¦ dp:å¯¹äºä»…åŒ…å«â€™1â€™ â€˜2â€™ çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²:â€œ1â€ : 1ç§ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼â€œ12â€ï¼š2ç§ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼â€œ111â€ï¼š3ç§ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼å…¶å®å°±æ˜¯dpçš„å…¥é—¨é¢˜â€œçˆ¬æ¥¼æ¢¯â€.å‡è®¾é•¿åº¦ä¸ºnçš„12ä¸²ä¸ºsteps[n] åˆ™steps[n] = steps[n - 1] + steps[n - 2]; int getNext(string target,int* next) { next[0] = -1; int k = -1; //é‡å¤å­ä¸²é•¿åº¦ä¸ºk for (int i = 1; i < target.size(); ++i)//è€ƒè™‘ï¼šç»ˆç‚¹æ˜¯target.size()-1è¿˜æ˜¯target.size()-2 { while (~k && (target[k + 1] != target[i]))//ä¸€å®šè¦æ³¨æ„æ¡ä»¶~kï¼Œå¦åˆ™å½“æ²¡æœ‰é‡å¤å­ä¸²æ—¶å°±ä¼šæ— é™å¾ªç¯ k = next[k]; //k = next[k]æ˜¯ä»£ç çš„æ ¸å¿ƒ //å¾ªç¯è·³å‡ºåï¼Œæœ‰ä¸¤ç§å¯èƒ½ï¼šk=-1æˆ–target[k+1]==target[i] è¿™ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œè‹¥target[k + 1] == target[i]ï¼Œå­—ä¸²é•¿åº¦å‡è¦+1 if (target[k + 1] == target[i]) ++k; next[i] = k; } return 0; } /*ä¸Šé¢è¿™ä¸ªå‡½æ•°å‡½æ•°å¤„ç†çš„æ•ˆæœï¼š ä»¥target = "abbcabbba"ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼Œå®ƒçš„æœ€ç»ˆå¾—åˆ°çš„nextæ•°ç»„ä¸ºï¼š{-1,-1,-1,-1,0,1,2,-1,0} */ int KMP(string source, string target) { int* next = new int[target.size()]; getNext(target, next); int i = 0, j = -1;//jä¸ºtargetï¼ˆæ¨¡å¼ä¸²ï¼‰çš„æŒ‡é’ˆã€‚ while (i < source.size()) { if (source[i] == target[j+1])//è‹¥ä¸¤æŒ‡é’ˆæ‰€æŒ‡å…ƒç´ ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œæ˜¾ç„¶è¦å³ç§»ã€‚ { ++i; ++j; } else if (j == -1)//è¯´æ˜æ²¡æœ‰é‡åˆå­ä¸²ï¼Œåªèƒ½è®©ç›®æ ‡ä¸²çš„æŒ‡é’ˆåŠ 1 ++i; else j = next[j];//source[i] != target[j]æ‰¾åˆ°jçš„ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªä½ç½® if (j == target.size()-1)//åŒ¹é…å®Œæ¯• break; } if (i >= target.length()) { delete[]next; return i - target.length(); } else { delete[]next; return -1; } } int main() { int next[20]; getNext("ABACDABABC", next); for (int i = 0; i < 10; ++i) cout << " " << next[i]; cout << "èµ·å§‹ä½ç½®ï¼š" << KMP("abababc", "bc"); }

posts.text: åŸé¢˜ä¼ é€é—¨->>> é¢˜ç›®æè¿°ï¼š Given a collection of integers that might contain duplicates, nums, return all possible subsets (the power set).Note: The solution set must not contain duplicate subsets. ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼š Input: [1,2,2] Output: [ [2], [1], [1,2,2], [2,2], [1,2], [] ] ç®€å•çš„å›æº¯é¢˜ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è‡ªå·±è§£å†³æ—¶é‡åˆ°å¾ˆå¤šé—®é¢˜ï¼Œè®°å½•ä¸€ä¸‹ã€‚ ACä»£ç  class Solution { public: vector<vector<int>>ans; vector<int> tmp; int* mark; vector<vector<int>> subsetsWithDup(vector<int>& nums) { sort(nums.begin(), nums.end()); mark = new int[nums.size()]; memset(mark, 0, 4 * nums.size()); for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); ++i) select(nums, i); delete[]mark; ans.push_back(vector<int>()); return ans; } void select(vector<int>& nums, int pos)//å°†è¦å–poså…ƒç´  { if (pos == nums.size()) return; if (pos && (nums[pos] == nums[pos - 1]) && (!mark[pos - 1])) return; else { tmp.push_back(nums[pos]); ans.push_back(tmp); mark[pos] = 1; for (int i = pos + 1; i < nums.size(); ++i) select(nums, i); tmp.pop_back(); mark[pos] = 0; } } }; å»é‡çš„è§„åˆ™æ¯”è¾ƒæ¸…æ¥šï¼šå…ˆè¿›è¡Œæ’åºã€‚å–è§„åˆ™ï¼šå½“å¤šä¸ªç›¸åŒæ•°å­—è¿ç»­å‡ºç°ï¼Œè¿™å‡ ä¸ªç›¸åŒæ•°å­—å¿…é¡»ä»å·¦åˆ°å³å–ï¼Œä¸èƒ½æœ‰é—´éš”ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼šarray = [1ï¼Œ2ï¼Œ3ï¼Œ3ï¼Œ3] å‡å¦‚ä¸å–array[2]ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆarray[3],array[4]ä¹Ÿä¸å¯ä»¥å–ã€‚é—®é¢˜åœ¨äºæœç´¢ä¸Šã€‚ WAä»£ç ç‰ˆæœ¬1 // for (int i = pos + 1; i < nums.size(); ++i) // select(nums, i); select(nums, pos + 1); è¿™ä¸ªç‰ˆæœ¬æ˜¯æ·±æœæ—¶ä»…ä»…æ¢æµ‹ä¸‹ä¸€æ ¼ã€‚å®ƒä¸å…è®¸è¿ç»­å–å…ƒç´ ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚array = [1ï¼Œ2ï¼Œ3ï¼Œ3ï¼Œ3]ï¼Œ[1,3]ä¸ä¼šå‡ºç°åœ¨ç­”æ¡ˆä¸­ WAä»£ç ç‰ˆæœ¬2 //if (pos && (nums[pos] == nums[pos - 1]) && (!mark[pos - 1])) // return; if (pos && (nums[pos] == nums[pos - 1]) && (!mark[pos - 1])) { for (int i = pos + 1; i < nums.size(); ++i) select(nums, i); return; } è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µï¼Œå½“å‘ç°é‡å¤å…ƒç´ ä¸ç¬¦åˆå–è§„åˆ™æ—¶,ä¼šå¯¹åé¢çš„æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ è¿›è¡Œæ¢æµ‹ã€‚é—®é¢˜åœ¨äºï¼Œå½“returnä¹‹åï¼Œè¯¥ç‚¹ä¹‹åçš„æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ ä¼šå†è¢«æ¢æµ‹ä¸€éï¼Œç»“æœç­”æ¡ˆä¼šæœ‰å¤§é‡é‡å¤ã€‚

posts.text: åŸé¢˜ä¼ é€é—¨â€”>>é¢˜ç›®æè¿°ï¼š æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªäºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ•°å­—ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œåœ¨è¯¥ç³»ç»Ÿä¸­ï¼Œä¸¤ä¸ªè¿ç»­çš„æ•°å€¼ä»…æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªä½æ•°çš„å·®å¼‚ã€‚ç»™å®šä¸€ä¸ªä»£è¡¨ç¼–ç æ€»ä½æ•°çš„éè´Ÿæ•´æ•° nï¼Œæ‰“å°å…¶æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—ã€‚å³ä½¿æœ‰å¤šä¸ªä¸åŒç­”æ¡ˆï¼Œä½ ä¹Ÿåªéœ€è¦è¿”å›å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ç§ã€‚æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—å¿…é¡»ä»¥ 0 å¼€å¤´ã€‚ ç¤ºä¾‹1ï¼š è¾“å…¥: 2è¾“å‡º: [0,1,3,2]è§£é‡Š:00 - 001 - 111 - 310 - 2å¯¹äºç»™å®šçš„ nï¼Œå…¶æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—å¹¶ä¸å”¯ä¸€ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œ[0,2,3,1] ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰æ•ˆçš„æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—ã€‚00 - 010 - 211 - 301 - 1 ç¤ºä¾‹2: è¾“å…¥: 0è¾“å‡º: [0]è§£é‡Š: æˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—å¿…é¡»ä»¥ 0 å¼€å¤´ã€‚ ç»™å®šç¼–ç æ€»ä½æ•°ä¸º n çš„æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—ï¼Œå…¶é•¿åº¦ä¸º 2nã€‚å½“ n = 0 æ—¶ï¼Œé•¿åº¦ä¸º 20 = 1ã€‚ å› æ­¤ï¼Œå½“ n = 0 æ—¶ï¼Œå…¶æ ¼é›·ç¼–ç åºåˆ—ä¸º [0]ã€‚ ä¸€é“èƒŒç­”æ¡ˆçš„é¢˜,è®°å½•ä¸€ä¸‹.æˆ‘å…ˆå‚è€ƒäº†ä¸‹é¢è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« :åŸæ–‡é“¾æ¥:æ ¼é›·ç Gray Codeè¯¦è§£ ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œæ”¹å˜æœ€å³è¾¹çš„ä½å…ƒå€¼ï¼› ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ï¼Œæ”¹å˜å³èµ·ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªä¸º1çš„ä½å…ƒçš„å·¦è¾¹ä½å…ƒï¼› ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ï¼Œç¬¬å››æ­¥é‡å¤ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥å’Œç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ï¼Œç›´åˆ°æ‰€æœ‰çš„æ ¼é›·ç äº§ç”Ÿå®Œæ¯•ï¼ˆæ¢å¥è¯è¯´ï¼Œå·²ç»èµ°äº†(2^n) - 1 æ­¥ï¼‰ã€‚ class Solution { public: vector<int> grayCode(int n) { vector<int> ans; if(!n) { ans.push_back(0); return ans; } int count = (1 << (n-1));//å…±éœ€è¦ç”Ÿæˆ2*countä¸ªæ•°å­—,å¾ªç¯countæ¬¡ int num = 0; for(int i = 0; i < count; ++i) { ans.push_back(num); num ^= 1; ans.push_back(num); change(num); } return ans; } void change(int &n)//æ”¹å˜nå³èµ·ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ºâ€˜1â€™çš„ä½çš„å·¦ä½ { int i = 1; int flag = 0; while(!flag)//flagä¸º1æ—¶é€€å‡ºå¾ªç¯ { flag = n & i; i = i << 1; } n = n ^ i; } }; è¯¥æ–¹æ¡ˆä»…ä»…å‡»è´¥äº†40% ,çœ‹åˆ°é¢˜è§£ä¸­æœ‰å¥—æ›´å¥½çš„ç®—æ³•:åŸæ–‡é“¾æ¥:Gray Code ï¼ˆé•œåƒåå°„æ³•ï¼Œå›¾è§£ï¼‰ æ‰€ä»¥ç”¨è¿™ç§æ€æƒ³æˆ‘åˆé‡å†™äº†ä»£ç : class Solution { public: vector<int> grayCode(int n) { vector<int> ans; ans.push_back(0); for(int i = 0; i < n; ++i) { int start = ans.size() - 1; for(int j = start; j >= 0; --j) { ans.push_back(ans[j] + (1 << i)); } } return ans; } }; æœç„¶100%kill

posts.title: leetcode 79. Word Search
posts.text: åŸé¢˜ä¼ é€é—¨â€”>é¢˜ç›®æè¿°ï¼šGiven a 2D board and a word, find if the word exists in the grid. The word can be constructed from letters of sequentially adjacent cell, where â€œadjacentâ€ cells are those horizontally or vertically neighboring. The same letter cell may not be used more than once. ç¤ºä¾‹ board = [ [â€˜Aâ€™,â€™Bâ€™,â€™Câ€™,â€™Eâ€™], [â€˜Sâ€™,â€™Fâ€™,â€™Câ€™,â€™Sâ€™], [â€˜Aâ€™,â€™Dâ€™,â€™Eâ€™,â€™Eâ€™] ] Given word = â€œABCCEDâ€, return true. Given word = â€œSEEâ€, return true. Given word = â€œABCBâ€, return false. æ ‡å‡†çš„æ·±æœé¢˜ï¼Œç›´æ¥ä¸Šä»£ç  class Solution { public: int **mark; bool exist(vector<vector<char>>& board, string word) { if(board.empty()) return false; mark = new int*[board.size()]; for(int i = 0; i < board.size(); ++i) { mark[i] = new int[board[0].size()]; memset(mark[i], 0, board[0].size()*4); } bool ans = false; for(int i = 0; i < board.size(); ++i) { for(int j = 0; j < board[0].size(); ++j) { if(find(board, word, i, j, 0)) { for(int k = 0; k < board.size(); ++k) { delete []mark[k]; } delete []mark; return true; } } } for(int k = 0; k < board.size(); ++k) { delete []mark[k]; } delete []mark; return false; } bool find(vector<vector<char>> & board, string & word,int row, int column, int pos) { if((row < 0)||(column < 0)||(row == board.size())||(column == board[0].size())) return false; if((mark[row][column])||(board[row][column] != word[pos])) return false; if(pos == word.size() - 1) return true; bool ans = false; mark[row][column] = 1; if(find(board, word, row - 1, column, pos + 1)|| find(board, word, row, column - 1, pos + 1)|| find(board, word, row + 1, column, pos + 1)|| find(board, word, row, column + 1, pos + 1)) return true; mark[row][column] = 0; return ans; } }; ä¸è¿‡è¿™é“é¢˜æœ‰ä¸€ç‚¹éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„ï¼šç¬¬47è¡Œä¹‹åè¿™ä¸€æ®µï¼šACç‰ˆæœ¬: bool ans = false; mark[row][column] = 1; if(find(board, word, row - 1, column, pos + 1)|| find(board, word, row, column - 1, pos + 1)|| find(board, word, row + 1, column, pos + 1)|| find(board, word, row, column + 1, pos + 1)) return true; mark[row][column] = 0; return ans; åŸæœ¬æˆ‘æ˜¯è¿™æ ·å†™çš„ï¼Œä¼šè¶…æ—¶ï¼šTLEç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š bool ans = false; mark[row][column] = 1; ans |= find(board, word, row - 1, column, pos + 1); ans |= find(board, word, row, column - 1, pos + 1); ans |= find(board, word, row + 1, column, pos + 1); ans |= find(board, word, row, column + 1, pos + 1); return true; mark[row][column] = 0; return ans; è¿™ä¸¤æ®µä»£ç æˆ‘ä¹‹å‰ä»¥ä¸ºæ˜¯ä¸€æ ·çš„ï¼Œä½†å…¶å®æ•ˆç‡å·®å¾ˆå¤šï¼Œçœ‹TLEç‰ˆæœ¬çš„ä»£ç ï¼šå‡å¦‚ansåœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ä¹‹åå°±å˜æˆtrueï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆä¹‹åçš„é€’å½’å·²ç»æ²¡æœ‰æ„ä¹‰äº†ï¼Œç›´æ¥returnå°±å¯ä»¥äº†ã€‚è€Œä½¿ç”¨ifåˆ¤æ–­æ—¶ï¼Œå¯¹äº||æ¡ä»¶ï¼Œå½“å‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶å€¼ä¸º1ï¼Œä¾¿ä¸ä¼šå†æ‰§è¡Œä¹‹åçš„è¯­å¥äº†ï¼Œç›¸å½“äºç›´æ¥return,æ‰€ä»¥æ•ˆç‡è¦é«˜å¾ˆå¤šã€‚

posts.text: åŸé¢˜ä¼ é€é—¨ â€”>> ç»™å‡ºé›†åˆ [1,2,3,â€¦,n]ï¼Œå…¶æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ å…±æœ‰ n! ç§æ’åˆ—ã€‚ æŒ‰å¤§å°é¡ºåºåˆ—å‡ºæ‰€æœ‰æ’åˆ—æƒ…å†µï¼Œå¹¶ä¸€ä¸€æ ‡è®°ï¼Œå½“ n = 3 æ—¶, æ‰€æœ‰æ’åˆ—å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š â€œ123â€â€œ132â€â€œ213â€â€œ231â€â€œ312â€â€œ321â€ç»™å®š n å’Œ kï¼Œè¿”å›ç¬¬ k ä¸ªæ’åˆ—ã€‚ è¯´æ˜ï¼š ç»™å®š n çš„èŒƒå›´æ˜¯ [1, 9]ã€‚ç»™å®š k çš„èŒƒå›´æ˜¯[1, n!]ã€‚ ç¤ºä¾‹ 1: è¾“å…¥: n = 3, k = 3è¾“å‡º: â€œ213â€ ç¤ºä¾‹ 2: è¾“å…¥: n = 4, k = 9è¾“å‡º: â€œ2314â€ å®¹æ˜“æƒ³åˆ°çš„æ˜¯æ·±æœï¼ˆå›æº¯ï¼‰ï¼Œä½† O(n!)çš„å¤æ‚åº¦å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥åˆ¤æ­»åˆ‘äº†ã€‚ï¼ˆä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘çœ‹é¢˜è§£é‡Œç¡®å®å›æº¯+å‰ªæè¿‡äº†çš„ï¼‰ä¸‹é¢çš„æ˜¯ç§åå‘æ•°å­¦çš„è§£æ³•ã€‚ æ€è·¯ï¼š å¯¹äº4ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼ˆ1ï¼Œ2ï¼Œ3ï¼Œ4ï¼‰ï¼Œ1å¼€å¤´çš„åºåˆ—æœ‰3! ã€å³6ä¸ªï¼Œ2å¼€å¤´çš„åŒç†ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå‡å¦‚è¦æ±‚ç¬¬15ä¸ªï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆä¸€å®šæ˜¯3ï¼ˆ(15-1)é™¤ä»¥6 å†åŠ 1ï¼‰å¼€å¤´ ç»§ç»­ï¼Œ3å·²ç»ç¡®å®šæ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼Œå‰©ä¸‹çš„æ•°å­—æœ‰1ï¼Œ2ï¼Œ4ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬æ¥ä¸‹æ¥éœ€è¦æ±‚1ã€3ã€4å…¨æ’åˆ—çš„ç¬¬3ï¼ˆ(15-1) mod 6ï¼‰ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼Œè§„åˆ™åŒä¸Šï¼Œåˆ™éœ€è¦ä»¥ç¬¬2ï¼ˆ3é™¤ä»¥2å†åŠ 1ï¼‰ä¸ªæ•°å­—å¼€å¤´ï¼Œ 2æ˜¯ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªæ•°å­— åŒä¸Šï¼Œ1æ˜¯ç¬¬3ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼Œ4æ˜¯ç¬¬4ä¸ªæ•°å­— ç­”æ¡ˆä¸º3214 15 - 1 = 6 Ã— 2 + 2 Ã— 1 + 1 Ã— 0 ï¼ˆ6ã€2ã€1åˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯3ã€2ã€1çš„é˜¶ä¹˜ï¼‰ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡å–ç¬¬3ã€2ã€1 ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼ˆå‰©ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—è‡ªåŠ¨è¡¥ä¸Šå°±å¯ä»¥ï¼‰100% killä»£ç ï¼š class Solution { public: string getPermutation(int n, int k) { vector<int> a; vector<int> b; for(int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) b.push_back(i); a.push_back(1); for(int i = 2; i < n; ++i) { a.push_back(a[i-2]*i); } int kk = k - 1; string ans; for(int i = 0; i < n-1; ++i) { int j = kk/a[n-2-i]; kk %= a[n-2-i]; ans.push_back(b[j] + '0'); b.erase(b.begin()+ j); } ans.push_back(b[0] + '0'); return ans; } };

posts.text: Trump or Biden, which candidate does China want in the White House? Analysis by Selina Wang, CNNUpdated 0950 GMT (1750 HKT) August 25, 2020 Hong Kong (CNN) â€” US President Donald Trump recently claimed that if his Democratic rival Joe Biden wins this Novemberâ€™s presidential election, China will â€œownâ€ the United States and Americans will have to learn to speak Chinese.The suggestion that Democrats are soft on China is a reoccurring policy theme that the President has returned to throughout his four years in oce. Now, as Trump prepares to take on Biden in a bid to secure a second term, his administration is once again amping up the anti-China rhetoric.Ahead of this weekâ€™s Republican National Convention, Trumpâ€™s campaign announced its second term agenda. The short document sets out 10 core priorities. Near the top of the agenda is â€œEnd our reliance on China,â€ listed right after â€œJobsâ€ and â€œEradicate Covid-19.â€The campaign said it plans to bring back 1 million manufacturing jobs from China and hold the country â€œfully accountable for allowing the virus to spread around the world.â€Since Trump took oce, relations between the two countries have spiraled to their lowest point in decades. Trump has waged a tari war, sanctioned Chinese ocials, angered Beijing with his support for Taiwan, and banned Chinese technology companies, including prized telecommunications giant Huawei.Though concerns about China have become decidedly more bipartisan in recent years, there remains a view among many in Washington that Chinese leaders would prefer a President Biden come 2021. Itâ€™s an idea that was given fresh impetus, after William Evanina, a top US intelligence ocial, said in a statement last month that Beijing would rather Trump lose the election.During a key note address at the opening night of the Republican convention, Monday, former ambassador to the United Nations and former governor of South Carolina Nikki Haley said Biden would be â€œgreat for Communist China.â€But experts say the reality is far more complex, and Chinaâ€™s leadership remains decidedly split on which candidate would better align with the countryâ€™s long-term strategic aims. Social media mockeryFrom Beijingâ€™s perspective, Trump appears to have weakened Americaâ€™s traditional alliances and international reputation. Chinese propaganda has cited Trumpâ€™s response to the pandemic, which has now killed more than 177,000 Americans, as proof of the USâ€™ failing political system and faltering global leadership. On Chinese social media, Trump has been mockingly named â€œChuan Jianguo,â€ or â€œBuild up the Country Trump,â€ with online users positing that Trump is bolstering Chinese President Xi Jinpingâ€™s regime by wrecking America. Although Trump has unleashed an onslaught of attacks on China in the form of taris, sanctions and bans, he has largely acted unilaterally, without the support of key allies.â€œThey know Biden will be a multilateralist, whether itâ€™s on trade, whether itâ€™s on security, whether itâ€™s even on human rights,â€ said Stephen Orlins, president of the National Committee on US-China Relations. â€œHe will have a multilateral approach to China and those people are fearful of a Biden presidency.â€ Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Osaka on June 29, 2019.During Trumpâ€™s presidency, China has been given a window to be more assertive on the international stage. After Trump announced Americaâ€™s withdrawal from the World Health Organization (WHO), Xi said China would provide $2 billion over two years to help with the global pandemic response. China has pressed ahead with a national security law in Hong Kong, hardened its stance on self-governing Taiwan, which China views as an inseparable part of its territory, and continued to aggressively push its claims of sovereignty in the disputed waters of the South China Sea. According to Minxin Pei, professor of government at Claremont McKenna College and author of â€œChinaâ€™s Crony Capitalism,â€ Biden would reinstate Americaâ€™s support for multilateral organizations, including the WHO, while strengthening trade and North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) military alliances â€” all of which would constrain China. Though Biden only mentioned China once in his acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention last week, he has repeatedly condemned Trump for being weak on China. Heâ€™s called Xi a â€œthugâ€ and his campaign ads have claimed Trump hasnâ€™t held China accountable for the spread of the pandemic, amid suggestions Chinese ocials covered up the initial outbreak. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden speaks at the Democratic National Convention on August 20 in Wilmington, Delaware. In the Democratsâ€™ sweeping 92-page party platform outlining policies including health care, climate change and the economy, China is mentioned 22 times. The document outlines how â€œDemocrats will take aggressive action against China or any other country that tries to undercut American manufacturing,â€ work with â€œallies to stand up to China,â€ condemn â€œChinaâ€™s mass internment of Uyghurs and other ethnic minoritiesâ€ in Xinjiang, and enforce sanctions on entities â€œresponsible for undercutting Hong Kongâ€™s autonomy.â€ Biden wrote in a Foreign Aairs article earlier this year that, â€œChina canâ€™t aord to ignore more than half the global economy. That gives us substantial leverage to shape the rules of the road on everything from the environment to labor, trade, technology, and transparency, so they continue to reflect democratic interests and values.â€Susan Shirk, chair of the 21st Century China Center at UC San Diego and former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State during the Clinton administration, said China has â€œlost a lot of friends in Asiaâ€ by using its economic power to coerce other countries into endorsing the Chinese line. â€œIf there is a Biden administration, building a stronger coalition in Asia will be a lot easier.â€ Trumpâ€™s â€˜unpredictabilityâ€™But whereas a Biden presidency would be challenging for Beijing, Trump presents something altogether dierent for risk-averse leaders in Beijing: volatility. In a recent US intelligence report compiled by top ocial Evanina, Trumpâ€™s â€œunpredictabilityâ€ was cited as a reason why China would prefer Biden.When Trump first took oce, he sang Xiâ€™s praises after they dined together at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. But that hasnâ€™t stopped him alternating between aiming threats at China and announcing that he and Xi â€œlove each other.â€ Experts say that this type of unpredictability increases the risk of military escalation, in areas where interests overlap, such as the South China Sea, East China Sea, and Taiwan. â€œWe do not have a good communications and crisis prevention with China the way we had with the Soviet Union during the Cold War,â€ Shirk said. â€œSo itâ€™s a very dangerous situation.â€ Chinese state media has called Biden â€œsmootherâ€ to deal with, creating room to cooperate on major international issues like climate change and nuclear non-proliferation. Henry Wang, an adviser to Chinaâ€™s cabinet and founder of the Center for Globalization, said that under a Biden administration, there would be more opportunities for dialogue. Pei said the split in Chinese attitudes toward Trump and Biden depend on whether ocials in Beijing are taking a short- or long-term view. Those who take a long-term view prefer Trump, since they view him as being incompetent and unable to get allies on board, thus giving China more room to maneuver. Another four years of Trump would lead to more internal divisions within America, reducing its ability to successfully wage a long-term struggle against China, Pei said. â€œThe Biden administration can devise a long-term strategy that is sustainable, that is multilateral with ally support, that will actually contain Chinese power, much more eectively for the next two to three decades,â€ Pei said. Those focused on the near-term would prefer Biden, since he would put a pause in the rapidly deteriorating relations. â€œA Biden administration will most likely have a pause in what I call this posts.text: â€œForced acquisition + only 45 days + intermediary fees are not comparable to Google. It is incredible,â€ he said.â€œå¼ºåˆ¶æ”¶è´­+ä»…æœ‰45å¤©æœŸé™+æ”¶å–ä¸­ä»‹è´¹ç”¨çš„è¡Œå¾„ä¸è°·æ­Œé€€å‡ºä¸­å›½ç»ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€å›äº‹ã€‚è¿™å¤ªä¸å¯æ€è®®äº†ï¼Œâ€ ä»–è¯´æœ¬æ–‡åœ¨å«æŠ¥å½“å¤©çš„é˜…è¯»é‡åœ¨å…¨ç«™ç¬¬5ä½ï¼Œå†…å®¹å‡ä¸ºåŸæ–‡åŸå›¾ï¼ˆä½†æ˜¯åŸæ–‡æ²¡æœ‰å›¾å“ˆå“ˆï¼‰ TikTok row: China hits out at US â€˜smash and grabâ€™ as tech dispute deepensForeign affairs spokesman accuses US of hypocrisy and editorial in state-run newspaper decries choice between submission at â€˜mortal combatâ€™ Helen Davidson Tue 4 Aug 2020 07.18 BST The US has offered China the â€œchoice of submission or mortal combat in the tech realmâ€, state media in Beijing have said, as the two rival powers manoeuvred on the thorny issue of splitting up TikTok. The popular video-sharing app has joined Huawei to become a technology flashpoint, with Chinese officials and media rushing to defend it following Donald Trumpâ€™s threat of a US ban. The US president later gave Microsoft until 15 September to make an acquisition deal with TikTokâ€™s parent company, ByteDance, and said the US Treasury should receive payment as part of the deal. As with his declaration on banning the app, he did not explain if, or how, this was possible. An editorial in the official state paper, China Daily, said China would not accept the â€œtheftâ€ of one of its technology companies, â€œand it has plenty of ways to respond if the administration carries out its planned smash and grabâ€. The US actions were driven by the profits in data, it said, and offered â€œan either-or choice of submission or mortal combat in the tech realmâ€. On Monday, a spokesman for Chinaâ€™s ministry of foreign affairs said China firmly opposed any US action against Chinese software companies over national security concerns. â€œThe US generalises the concept of national security and, without any evidence, presumptions of guilt and threats against relevant companies,â€ said Wang Wenbin. â€œThis violates the principles of market economy and exposes the hypocrisy and typical double standards of the US in maintaining fairness and freedom. It also violates the World Trade Organisationâ€™s principles of openness, transparency and non-discrimination.â€ Chinaâ€™s ambassador to the UK, Liu Xiaoming, also accused the US of hypocrisy. â€œIt is the US that has politicised economic issues and abused the concept of national security to pursue discriminatory and exclusive policies,â€ he said. Kai-Fu Lee, the former president of Google China, said the US treatment of TikTok was â€œunbelievableâ€. Lee said China set out clear rules for tech companies to comply with if they wanted to do business in the country, and Google had decided not to stay on that basis. He accused the US of giving no parameters for TikTok to work with, or providing any evidence for their national security claims â€œGoogle didnâ€™t want to comply with Chinese laws & regulations, so it quit,â€ said Lee, who added he had left the company prior to its exit from China. â€œForced acquisition + only 45 days + intermediary fees are not comparable to Google. It is incredible,â€ he said. An editorial in Chinaâ€™s state-owned 21st Century Business Herald said forcing the sale would set a â€œdangerous precedentâ€. â€œFor this transaction, the Chinese government may also consider reviewing whether the technology transfer in it violates Chinese laws and harms Chinaâ€™s national interests.â€ ByteDance has not confirmed any discussions with Microsoft, but an internal staff memo from founder Zhang Yiming addressed the speculation on Monday. Separately on Monday the company also said it was considering establishing TikTokâ€™s headquarters outside the US. The reports prompted some backlash on Chinese social media, with some accusing the company of surrendering to the US, which was akin â€œto being anti-Chinaâ€. â€œChoose wisely on selling to the United States or becoming an enemy at home,â€ wrote one user. Additional reporting by Pei Lin Wu Topics: China TikTok Asia Pacific news è¯‘æ–‡ï¼š Tiktokä¹‹äº‰ï¼š posts.excerpt: Hawkish U.S. politicians come and go, this Chinese giant is playing a much longer game.ç¾å›½çš„é¹°æ´¾æ”¿å®¢æ¥æ¥å¾€å¾€ï¼Œè€Œè¿™ä¸ªä¸­å›½å·¨å¤´æ­£åœ¨ç©ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´é•¿çš„æ¸¸æˆã€‚â€
posts.text: Hawkish U.S. politicians come and go, this Chinese giant is playing a much longer game.ç¾å›½çš„é¹°æ´¾æ”¿å®¢æ¥æ¥å¾€å¾€ï¼Œè€Œè¿™ä¸ªä¸­å›½å·¨å¤´æ­£åœ¨ç©ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´é•¿çš„æ¸¸æˆã€‚â€ æˆªæ­¢7æœˆ21æ—¥ï¼Œæœ¬æ–‡åœ¨Forbesé˜…è¯»é‡ä¸º37435äººæ¬¡ Yes, Trump Just Seriously Damaged Huaweiâ€”But This Isnâ€™t Over YetContributor: Zak Doffman VCG VIA GETTY IMAGES We now have confirmation, if any was needed, that the U.K.â€™s decision to ban Huawei from its 5G network came as a direct result of pressure from U.S. President Trump and his security team. There was also the non-trivial issue of an about-turn in the advice from Britainâ€™s spooks to its politiciansâ€”the risks with Huawei equipment could no longer be mitigated. This, again, was directly attributable to Americaâ€™s campaign against the Chinese tech giant. On the surface, this may look like a victory for Washington, but itâ€™s not that simpleâ€”Huawei is far from defeated. The clear implication in the U.K. is that the Huawei decision is all about politics and has little to do with security. The U.K. cyber team charged with defending the realm from the threats associated with Chinese equipment have only changed their view because, at Americaâ€™s insistence, U.S. components inside Huawei equipment are being replaced by (likely) Chinese equivalents. A change in the political windsâ€”thereâ€™s a U.S. election now just a few months away â€”and both the lobbying and the supply chain restrictions could easily fall away. This context behind the U.K.â€™s â€œmateriallyâ€ changed security report, that the change was fabricated by the U.S., is critical. Absent the latest sanctions, the U.K. advice would not have changed and the reason driving the U.K.â€™s reversal would not exist. The confirmation from leading chip supplier TSMC, that it will cease supplying Huawei in September per new U.S. rules, was also steeped in the implication that were those rules to soften or change, or were the company to successfully apply for a license to supply, than weâ€™d be quickly back to normal. Even the structure of the U.K.â€™s newly announced reversal is all about the detail. The decision to bar purchases of 5G equipment from next January leaves a sizeable procurement window wide open, and is designed to restrict the acquisition of standalone 5G kit rather than LTE-to-5G upgrades. The long grace period (until 2027) before a rip and replace is mandatory, and the silence on existing 3G and 4G equipment already deployed, have left many options on the table. If a week is a long time in politics, seven years is a lifetime. Trump was quick to take credit for the U.K. decision, personalizing the victory, and itâ€™s true that the president has campaigned long and hard to persuade his key defense and intelligence ally to toe the U.S. line. But Washingtonâ€™s relationship with Beijing is starkly different to Londonâ€™s. The U.S. can brush aside economic threats from Chinaâ€”neither can live without the other. A U.K. facing up to the harsh realities of a post-COVID Brexit is not in such a fortunate position. China issued further threats of â€œretaliationâ€ in the wake of the Huawei decision. And that carries some weight in a country reliant on Chinese investments in infrastructure and technology, and with a huge install base of Huawei equipment. Huaweiâ€™s U.K. PR chief, Ed Brewster, stressed during a charged BBC Newsnight interview last week, that the companyâ€™s mission in the U.K. continues. R&D investments and the decision, announced post the 5G reversal, to open new flagship stores should tell you all you need to know about where Huawei stands on its U.K. future. â€œWe know that millions of people here in the U.K. love our products,â€ the company said on announcing the Â£10 million (\$12.5 million) investment. Hawkish U.S. politicians come and go, this Chinese giant is playing a much longer game. The group of U.K. politicians that has lobbied its government hard for tougher sanctions on Huawei knows there is a risk of further changes as this story runs through Novemberâ€™s U.S. election and whatever fallout we see from inquiries into the origins of coronavirus and Beijingâ€™s alleged misinformation. There is also a much wider technology stand-off, one that has now dragged the TikTok into the mix. The U.S. is fast approaching a decision point as to just how far it wants to take this, before the implications on its own technology sector become much harder to sell back home. The headlines might be filled these days with news of new investments into India, but China is China, and itâ€™s not going to be easily displaced as the worldâ€™s centre of tech manufacturing and the worldâ€™s hottest consumer market. Stepping back from this seminal week in the battle between the U.S. and Huawei, itâ€™s hard not to think that the U.K. has left the door ajar for further twists and turns. The decision is solely based on U.S. lobbying and sanctions, and the U.K. does not want to be left holding the check should the U.S. change its tone. # posts.excerpt: With flu season on the horizon and Donald Trump demanding that millions of students return to school in the fall â€“ not to mention a presidential election quickly approaching â€“ the country appears at risk of being torn apart.æµæ„Ÿå­£èŠ‚å³å°†åˆ°æ¥ã€å¤§é€‰ä¸´è¿‘ã€æ€»ç»Ÿåˆè¦æ±‚å­¦æ ¡ç§‹å­£å¼€å­¦â€”â€”ç¾å›½æ­£é¢ä¸´è¢«æ’•è£‚çš„å±é™©ã€‚
posts.text: With flu season on the horizon and Donald Trump demanding that millions of students return to school in the fall â€“ not to mention a presidential election quickly approaching â€“ the country appears at risk of being torn apart.æµæ„Ÿå­£èŠ‚å³å°†åˆ°æ¥ã€å¤§é€‰ä¸´è¿‘ã€æ€»ç»Ÿåˆè¦æ±‚å­¦æ ¡ç§‹å­£å¼€å­¦â€”â€”ç¾å›½æ­£é¢ä¸´è¢«æ’•è£‚çš„å±é™©ã€‚æœ¬æ–‡åœ¨å«æŠ¥å½“å¤©çš„é˜…è¯»é‡åœ¨å…¨ç«™ç¬¬2ä½ï¼Œå†…å®¹å‡ä¸ºåŸæ–‡åŸå›¾ The virus doesnâ€™t care about excusesâ€™:US faces terrifying autumn as Covid19 urgesThe breathing space afforded by lockdowns in the spring has been squandered, with new cases running at five times the rate ofthe whole of Europe. Things will only get worse, experts warn by Tom McCarthy in New YorkCoronavirus latest global updatesMain image: Composite: Guardian Design/Getty/ShutterstockSat 18 Jul 2020 06.00 BST In early June, the United States awoke from a months-long nightmare.Coronavirus had brutalized the north-east, with New York City alone recording more than 20,000 deaths, the bodies piling up in refrigerated trucks. Thousands sheltered at home. Rice, flour and toilet paper ran out. Millions of jobs disappeared. But then the national curve flattened, governors declared success and patrons returned to restaurants, bars and beaches. â€œWe are winning the fight against the invisible enemy,â€ vicepresident Mike Pence wrote in a 16 June op-ed, titled, â€œThere isnâ€™t a coronavirus â€˜second waveâ€™.â€ Except, in truth, the nightmare was not over â€“ the country was not awake â€“ and a new wave of cases was gathering with terrifying force. As Pence was writing, the virus was spreading across the American south and interior, finding thousands of untouched communities and infecting millions of new bodies. Except for the precipitous drop in New York cases, the curve was not flat at all. It was surging, in line with epidemiological predictions. Now, four months into the pandemic, with test results delayed, contact tracing scarceï¼Œ protective equipment dwindling and emergency rooms once again filling, the United States finds itself in a fight for its life: swamped by partisanship, mistrustful of science, engulfed in mask wars and led by a president whose ncompetence is rivaled only by his indifference to Americansâ€™ suffering. With flu season on the horizon and Donald Trump demanding that millions of students return to school in the fall â€“ not to mention a presidential election quickly approaching â€“ the country appears at risk of being torn apart. â€œI feel like itâ€™s March all over again,â€ said William Hanage, a professor of epidemiology at the Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health. â€œThere is no way in which a large number of cases of disease, and indeed a large number of deaths, are going to be avoided.â€ The problem facing the United States is plain. New cases nationally are up a remarkable 50% over the last two weeks and the daily death toll is up 42% over the same period. Cases are on the rise in 40 out of 50 states, Washington DC and Puerto Rico. Last week America recorded more than 75,000 new cases daily â€“ five times the rate of all Europe. â€œWe are unfortunately seeing more higher daily case numbers than weâ€™ve ever seen, even exceeding pre-lockdown times,â€ said Jennifer Nuzzo, an epidemiologist at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security. â€œThe number of new cases that occur each day in the US are greater than weâ€™ve yet experienced. So this is obviously a very worrisome direction that weâ€™re headed in.â€ Donald Trump speaks to the media before boarding Marine One on 10 July to head to coronavirus-stricken Florida as he ramps up public appearances ahead of the election. Photograph: Shawn Thew/Bloomberg/Getty Images The mayor of Houston, Texas, proposed a â€œtwo-week shutdownâ€ last week after cases in the state climbed by tens of thousands. The governor of California reclosed restaurants, churches and bars, while the governors of Louisiana, Alabama and Montana made mask-wearing in public compulsory.â€œToday I am sounding the alarm,â€ Governor Kate Brown said. â€œWe are at risk of Covid-19 getting out of control in Oregon.â€ As dire as the current position seems, the months ahead look even worse. The country anticipates hundred of thousands of hospitalizations, if the annual averages hold, during the upcoming flu season. Those hospitalizations will further strain the capacity of overstretched clinics. But a flu outbreak could also hamper the countryâ€™s ability to fight coronavirus in other ways. Because the two viruses have similar symptoms â€“ fever, chills, diarrhea, fatigue â€“ mistaken diagnoses could delay care for some patients until itâ€™s too late, and make outbreaks harder to catch, one of the countryâ€™s top health officials has warned. â€œI am worried,â€ Dr Robert Redfield, the director of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), said last week. â€œI do think the fall and the winter of 2020 and 2021 are probably going to be one of the most difficult times that we have experienced in American public health because of â€¦ the co-occurrence of Covid and influenza.â€ Other factors will be in play. A precipitous reopening of schools in the fall, as demanded by Trump and the education secretary, Betsy DeVos, without safety measures recommended by the CDC, could create new superspreader events, with unknown consequences for children. â€œWe would expect that to be throwing fuel on the fire,â€ said Hanage of blanket school reopenings. â€œSo itâ€™s going to be bad over the next month or so. You can pretty much expect it to be getting worse in the fall.â€ The list of aggravating circumstances goes on and on. A federal unemployment assistance program that gave each claimant an extra 600 a month is set to expire at the end of July. A new coronavirus relief package is being held up in Congress by Republicansâ€™ accusations that states are wasting money, and their insistence that any new legislation include liability protections for businesses that reopen during the pandemic. Customers shop for fruit at a street vendor in the Corona neighborhood in Queens, New York, on 27 June. Photograph: Amir Hamja/Bloomberg/Getty Images Cable broadcasts and social media have been filled, meanwhile, with video clips of furious confrontations on sidewalks, in stores and streets over wearing facial masks. In Michigan, a sheriffâ€™s deputy shot dead a man who had stabbed another man for challenging him about not wearing a mask at a convenience store. In Georgia, the Republican governor sued the Democratic mayor of Atlanta for issuing a city-wide mask mandate. The partisan divide on masks is slowly closing as the outbreaks intensify. The share of Republicans saying they wear masks whenever they leave home rose 10 points to 45% in the first two weeks of July, while 78% of Democrats reported doing so, according to an Axios-Ipsos poll. Another divide has proven tragically resilient. As hotspots have shifted south, the virus continues to affect Black and Latinx communities disproportionately. Members of those communities are three times as likely to become infected and twice as likely to die from the virus as white people, according to data from early July. The raging virus has prompted speculation in some corners that the only way out for the United States is through some kind of â€œherd immunityâ€ achieved by simply giving up. But that grossly underestimates the human tragedy such a scenario would involve, epidemiologists say, in the form of tens of millions of new cases and unknown thousands of deaths. â€œI think that every single serology study thatâ€™s been done to date suggests that the vast majority of Americans have not yet been exposed to this virus,â€ Nuzzo said. â€œSo weâ€™re still very much in the early stages. â€œWhich is good, thatâ€™s actually really good news. I donâ€™t want to strive for herd immunity, because that means the vast majority of us will get sick and that will mean many, many more deaths. The point is to slow the spread as much as possible, protect ourselves as much as possible, until we have other tools.â€ But the ability of the US to take that basic step â€“ to slow the spread, as dozens of other countries have done â€“ is in perilous doubt. After half a year, the Trump administration has made no effort to establish a national protocol for testing, contact tracing and supported isolation â€“ the same proven three-pronged strategy by which other countries control their outbreaks. Critics say that instead, Trump has dithered and denied as the national death toll climbed to almost 140,000. The Democratic presidential candidate, Joe Biden, who is hoping to unseat Trump in November, blasted the president for refusing until recently to wear a mask in public. â€œHe wasted four months that Americans have been making sacrifices by stoking divisions and actively discouraging people from taking a very basic step to protect each other,â€ Biden said in a statement last weekend. A healthcare worker talks to a patient in the ER at Oakbend medical center in Richmond, Texas, on 15 July. Photograph: Mark Felix/AFP/Getty Images Meanwhile the White House has attacked Dr Anthony Fauci, the countryâ€™s foremost expert on infectious diseases whose refusal to lie to the public has enraged Trump, by publishing an oped signed by one of the presidentâ€™s top aides titled â€œAnthony Fauci has been wrong about everything I have interacted with him onâ€ and by releasing a file of opposition research to the Washington Post. Trump claimed the number of cases was a function of unusually robust testing, though experts said that positivity rates of 20% in multiple states suggested that the United States is testing too little â€“ and that in any case closing oneâ€™s eyes to the problem by testing less would not make it go away. â€œWeâ€™ve done 45 million tests,â€ Trump said this week, padding the figure only slightly. â€œIf we did half that number, youâ€™d have half the cases, probably around that number. If we did another half of that, youâ€™d have half the numbers. Everyone would be saying weâ€™re doing well on cases.â€ Such statements by Trump have encouraged unfavorable comparisons of the US pandemic response with those in countries such as Italy, which recorded just 169 new cases on Monday after a horrific spring, and South Korea, which has kept cases in the low double-digits since April. The Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, walks to his office from the Senate floor on 13 May. Photograph: Shawn Thew/EPA But the United States could also look to many African countries for lessons in pandemic response, said Amanda McClelland, who runs a global epidemic prevention program at Resolve to Save Lives. â€œWeâ€™ve seen some good success in countries like Ghana, who have really focused on contact tracing, and being able to follow up superspreading events,â€ said McClelland. â€œWe see Ethiopia: they kept their borders open for a lot longer than other countries, but they have really aggressive testing and active case-finding to make sure that theyâ€™re not missing cases. â€œI think what weâ€™ve seen is that you need not just a strong health system but strong leadership and governance to be able to manage the outbreak, and weâ€™ve seen countries that have all three do well.â€ Factory workers produce personal protective equipment for coronavirus frontline health workers at a factory commissioned by the government, in Accra, Ghana, on 17 April. The US pandemic response compares unfavorably with a number of African countries. Photograph: Nipah Dennis/AFP/Getty Images But in America, the large laboratories that process Covid-19 tests are unable to keep up with demand. Quest Diagnostics announced on Tuesday that its average turnaround time for test results was a minimum of seven days for most patients. â€œWe want patients and healthcare providers to know that we will not be in a position to reduce our turnaround times as long as cases of Covid-19 continue to increase dramatically,â€ the lab said. â€œYou canâ€™t have unlimited lab capacity, and what weâ€™ve done is allow, to some extent, cases to go beyond our capacity,â€ said McClelland. â€œWeâ€™re never going to be able to treat and track and trace uncontrolled transmission. This outbreak is just too infectious.â€ Public health experts emphasize that the United States does not have to accept as its fate a cascade of tens of millions of new cases, and tens of thousands of deaths, in the months ahead. Focused leadership and individual resolve could yet help the country follow in the footsteps of other nations that have successfully faced serious outbreaks â€“ and brought them under control. But it is clear that the most vulnerable Americans, including the elderly and those with preexisting conditions, face grave danger. Republicans have argued in recent weeks that while cases in the US have soared, death rates are not climbing so quickly, because the new cases are disproportionately affecting younger adults. That is a false reassurance, health experts say, because deaths are a lagging indicator â€“ cases necessarily rise before deaths do â€“ and because large outbreaks among any demographic group speeds the virusâ€™s ability to get inside nursing homes, care facilities and other places where residents are most vulnerable. â€œIf we donâ€™t do anything to stop the virus, itâ€™s going to be very difficult to prevent it from getting to people who will die,â€ said Nuzzo. A United States flag flies at half-mast outside the Hammonton center for rehabilitation and healthcare in Hammonton, New Jersey, on 19 May. Photograph: Lucas Jackson/Reuters There is a question of whether the United States, for all its wealth and expertise â€“ and its selfregard as an exceptional actor on the world stage â€“ can summon the will to keep up the fight. People are tired of fighting the virus, and of fighting each other. â€œI think unfortunately people are emotionally exhausted from having to think about and worry about this virus,â€ said Nuzzo. â€œThey feel like theyâ€™ve already sacrificed a lot. So the worry that I have is, what willingness is there left, to do what it takes?â€ It is as if the country is â€œtreading water in the middle of the oceanâ€, Hanage said. â€œPeople tend to be shuffling very quickly between denial and fatalism,â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s really not helpful. There are a number of things that can be done. â€œWhat I would hope is that this marks a point when the United States finally wakes up and realizes that this is a pandemic and starts taking it seriously. â€œFolks tend to look at what has happened elsewhere and then they make up some kind of magical reason why itâ€™s not going to happen to them. â€œPeople keep making these excuses, and the virus doesnâ€™t care about the excuses. The virus just keeps going. If you give it the opportunity, it will take it.â€ America faces an epic choice â€¦â€¦ in the coming months, and the results will define the country for a generation. These are perilous times. Over the last three years, much of what the Guardian holds dear has been threatened â€“ democracy, civility, truth. The country is at a crossroads. Science is in a battle with conjecture and instinct to determine policy in the middle of a pandemic. At the same time, the US is reckoning with centuries of racial injustice â€“ as the White House stokes division along racial lines. At a time like this, an independent news organisation that fights for truth and holds power to account is not just optional. posts.excerpt: The UK now wants to offer BNO passport holders citizenship rights after six years of stay, arguing that China has breached the Sino-British Joint Declaration by enacting the national security law, which violates the cityâ€™s high degree of autonomy and infringes the civil liberties of Hong Kong residents.è‹±å›½ç°åœ¨å¸Œæœ›ç»™äºˆè‹±å›½æŠ¤ç…§æŒæœ‰è€…åœ¨å±…ç•™å…­å¹´åçš„å…¬æ°‘æƒåˆ©ï¼Œè§£é‡Šç§°é¦™æ¸¯å›½å®‰æ³•è¿åäº†â€œä¸­è‹±è”åˆå£°æ˜â€ï¼Œç ´åäº†åŸå¸‚çš„é«˜åº¦è‡ªæ²»ï¼Œä¾µçŠ¯äº†é¦™æ¸¯å…¬æ°‘è‡ªç”±ã€‚
posts.text: The UK now wants to offer BNO passport holders citizenship rights after six years of stay, arguing that China has breached the Sino-British Joint Declaration by enacting the national security law, which violates the cityâ€™s high degree of autonomy and infringes the civil liberties of Hong Kong residents.è‹±å›½ç°åœ¨å¸Œæœ›ç»™äºˆè‹±å›½æŠ¤ç…§æŒæœ‰è€…åœ¨å±…ç•™å…­å¹´åçš„å…¬æ°‘æƒåˆ©ï¼Œè§£é‡Šç§°é¦™æ¸¯å›½å®‰æ³•è¿åäº†â€œä¸­è‹±è”åˆå£°æ˜â€ï¼Œç ´åäº†åŸå¸‚çš„é«˜åº¦è‡ªæ²»ï¼Œä¾µçŠ¯äº†é¦™æ¸¯å…¬æ°‘è‡ªç”±ã€‚ æœ¬æ–‡åœ¨BBC news å½“å¤©çš„é˜…è¯»é‡æ’åœ¨ç¬¬ 5ä½ï¼Œå†…å®¹å‡ä¸ºåŸæ–‡åŸå›¾ã€‚ä»…ç”¨äºæ·±å…¥äº†è§£äº‹ä»¶ï¼Œè¥¿æ–¹ä¸å›½å†…çš„ä»·å€¼è§‚ä¸åŒï¼Œè¯·æ—¶åˆ»ä¿æŒç†æ€§,â€œäººæƒâ€å’Œâ€œè‡ªç”±â€ç»ä¸æ˜¯å¹²æ¶‰ä¸­å›½å†…æ”¿çš„æ­£å½“ç†ç”± å›¾ç‰‡åœ¨æ‰‹æœºé¡µé¢ç»å¸¸ä¸èƒ½åŠ è½½ï¼Œæ¨èç§»æ­¥PCç«¯ Hong Kong security law: Why we are taking our BNOs and leavingBy Grace Tsoi BBC News, Hong Kong12 July 2020  Since China imposed a draconian national security law on Hong Kong, a lot of dinner party chatter in this protest-minded city has been about personal exit strategies. For up to three million Hongkongers, the exit could come in the form of a British National (Overseas) passport. Will they really leave - and what of those left behind? Michael and Serena have decided to leave Hong Kong for good and settle in the UK, a country they have never set foot in.The couple have British National (Overseas) - or BNO - passports, which were issued to Hong Kong residents that registered before the city was handed back to China on July 1997.Essentially a travel document with rights for some consular assistance, its usefulness seemed limited to many for anything but easier access to the UK and European travel. Some people went for it anyway. Why not, went the thinking for many Hongkongers. Michael and Serena are the embodiment of the comfortable prosperity common in Hong Kong: well-travelled with a 13-year-old daughter, they are both middle managers in a bank and bought a flat many years ago. It is a lot to give up. They say that Hong Kong has become unrecognisable in its handling of the months-long protests triggered by a bill which proposed to allow extradition to mainland China. What the couple saw was a government which did not listen to the people, and police force that showed little restraint.Their daughter has been deeply affected by the protests, even though the family did not take part because the couple work at a Chinese bank, where an employee was fired for protesting.â€œShe has been very angry and upset. She kept asking why the authorities could treat us like that?â€ Serena said, adding that their daughter had told them she wanted to study abroad.The controversial national security law, which took effect last week, was the last straw.â€œThe articles of the national security law are outrageous,â€ said Michael. Serena said she did not believe Beijingâ€™s claims that the claim that law would only target â€œa tiny number of peopleâ€. The UK now wants to offer BNO passport holders citizenship rights after six years of stay, arguing that China has breached the Sino-British Joint Declaration by enacting the national security law, which violates the cityâ€™s high degree of autonomy and infringes the civil liberties of Hong Kong residents.Michael and Serenaâ€™s original plan was to only send their daughter to study abroad, but now moving to the UK as a family has become their first choice. Last November, they renewed their long-expired BNO passports, thinking that it could become useful - a hedge against an uncertain future.â€œI thought the UK would only offer citizenship to BNO passport holders as a last resort. I didnâ€™t think it would happen so soon, but all of a sudden great changes are happening,â€ Michael said.In the week since China announced the new security law, the story of Michael and Serena has become more common. The people without BNO passports BNO passports were issued to people who registered before the former British colony was handed back to China Currently, there are about 350,000 BNO passport holders in Hong Kong, and the UK government estimates that there are about 2.9 million BNOs in total.Hong Kong residents born after the 1997 handover are not eligible for the BNO passport - and those who did not apply for one before the handover are not allowed to do so now.Helen was born in 1997 before the handover, but her parents did not apply for a BNO passport for her because she was a baby.â€œI am not sure if I want to go. But this is my right. Compared to the UK, I like Hong Kong more. But I should have had a BNO passport,â€ she said, admitting that she blamed her parents a little for not applying for one for her back then. About 350,000 Hong Kong residents are BNO passport holders as of February It is difficult to gauge the number of Hong Kong residents who will take up the UK's offer at this moment - but interest is running high, especially after the UK's announcement on July 1. On that day, Mr Raab told the House of Commons: "We will not look the other way on Hong Kong, and we will not duck our historic responsibilities to its people." Ben Yu, who works for an immigration consultancy in the UK, said: "My Hong Kong-based colleague receives 30 to 40 messages on Facebook every day. His WhatsApp has received hundreds of messages asking about moving to the UK by all routes, including BNOs and other visas. The messages come in 24/7 non-stop since then." The number of BNO renewals appears to be driven by political upheavals in Hong Kong. In 2018, about 170,000 BNO passports were in circulation. The next year, the number jumped to more than 310,000. During the colonial days, Hong Kong was always described as a borrowed place on borrowed time - and it is no stranger to waves of emigration. Between 1984 and 1997, between about 20,000 and 66,000 people left the city every year. The imminent wave of emigration will also likely look different to those in the past. "A lot of them returned to Hong Kong either before 1997 or after 1997, when they had seized their safety outlets when they had got their foreign passports, when they saw that the political nightmare had not occurred as predicted," said Professor Ming Sing, who teaches politics at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. "For the current wave, should it happen, I guess we will see a higher proportion of them is going to be a one-way ticketï¼Œ" he said. "A lot of them see that the legislation of the national security law which has been imposed from the top is not only draconian in nature, but it also reflects Beijing reneging on its promise. Not only its failure to protect Hong Kong's freedoms under the Joint Declaration and under the Basic Law," he said, adding that he thinks more young people, many of them are protesters, will exit Hong Kong. ## What comes next? In the city of 7.5 million, about 800,000 people have British, Australian, Canadian, or American passports - including expats. Beijing has expressed anger over the UK's plan to offer citizenship to BNO passport holders in Hong Kong. China's Ambassador to the UK Liu Xiaoming said on Monday the move constitutes **"gross interference in China's internal affairs"** "No one should underestimate the firm determination of China to safeguard its sovereignty, security and development interests," he said. The Chinese Embassy also said in a statement all "Chinese compatriots residing in Hong Kong are Chinese nationals". In an earlier interview with ITV, Mr Raab said there is little the UK could do if China doesn't allow Hong Kong residents to come to the UK. "It is hard to predict what consequences Beijing has in mind. Probably more diplomatic ones in the form of a counter-measure, which does not necessarily need to be in the same form but should not be disproportionate," said Simon Young, a legal scholar at the University of Hong Kong. Benedict Rogers, co-founder and chair of advocacy group Hong Kong Watch, described the BNO offer as "generous, courageous and welcome". (video: Hong Kongers with British passports are divided over whether to leave the country) But the rescue element should be a last resort, Mr Rogers said. "We should be working to ensure the conditions are met whereby HongKongers can continue their way of life, with the freedoms they were promised, without having to flee their homes. But the reality is that now, for some, it is already too late and they will need a place of sanctuary." Michael and Serena are making preparations for a new life in the UK, but they did not succeed at convincing their older son, who is turning 18 soon, to leave with them. He will live with his grandparents after the rest of the family has moved. "My son says he doesn't want to leave Hong Kong, because he thinks Hong Kong belongs to him," Serena said. *Some names have been changed.* *----end---* IsEulerRoad()) //å‡å¦‚ä¸æ˜¯æ¬§æ‹‰è·¯ï¼ˆä½†ç”±äºç¯çš„å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œå…¶å®å¹¶éå……åˆ†æ¡ä»¶,åé¢è¿˜è¦åˆ¤æ–­ï¼‰ { cout << â€œ***â€ << endl; return 0; } Travel(); //éå†ï¼Œå¹¶è®°å½•ç­”æ¡ˆ Output();//è¾“å‡º return 0; } å®Œæ•´ACä»£ç ï¼š #include<iostream> #include<string> #include<algorithm> #include<list> using namespace std; string words[1002];//è®°å½•æ‰€æœ‰å•è¯ int mark[1001];//éå†æ—¶ä½œæ ‡è®° int num = 0;//è¾¹ï¼ˆå³å•è¯ï¼‰çš„æ€»æ•° int Ptr[28]; //ç´¢å¼•é›†ï¼Œè®°å½•words[] ä¸­ä»¥26ä¸ªå­—æ¯ä¸ºé¦–å­—æ¯çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå•è¯ä¸‹æ ‡ int Begin;//éå†èµ·ç‚¹ int ans[1002];//å­˜å‚¨éå†è·¯å¾„ int flag = false;//æ ‡è®°æ˜¯å¦éå†ç»“æŸ void SetPtr(); //åˆå§‹åŒ–Ptr void travel(int s,int depth); int InDegree[28];//26ä¸ªå­—æ¯çš„å…¥åº¦ int OutDegree[28];//26ä¸ªå­—æ¯çš„å‡ºåº¦ bool IsEulerRoad(); int main() { cin >> num; for(int i = 0; i < num; ++i) { cin >> words[i]; char apple = words[i][0]; char banana = words[i][words[i].size()-1]; ++OutDegree[apple - 'a']; ++InDegree[banana - 'a']; } sort(words,words+num);//æŒ‰å­—å…¸åºæ’åº SetPtr(); if(!IsEulerRoad()) { cout << "***" << endl; return 0; } travel(Begin,1); if(!flag)//æ’é™¤å›è·¯çš„å¹²æ‰°ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚è¾“å…¥æ•°æ®ä¸ºï¼š2 a bã€‚ { cout << "***" <<endl; return 0; } cout << words[ans[0]]; for(int i = 1; i < num; ++i) { cout << "." << words[ans[i]]; } cout << endl; return 0; } void SetPtr() { int j = 0; for(int i = 0; i < num; ++i) { int k = (char)(words[i][0]) - 'a'; if(k < j) continue; while(k > j) { Ptr[j] = i; ++j; } Ptr[j] = i; ++j; } for(;j < 27;++j ) Ptr[j] = num; return; } void travel(int s,int depth) { ans[depth - 1] = s; if(depth == num) { flag = true; return; } mark[s] = 1;//æ ‡è®° int next = (words[s][words[s].size()-1])-'a'; int start = Ptr[next]; int end = Ptr[next+1];//ç´¢å¼•é›†æ´¾ä¸Šç”¨åœº for(int itr = start; itr < end; ++itr)//éå†æ‰€æœ‰è¾¹ { if(!mark[itr]) { travel(itr,depth+1); mark[itr] = 0; if(flag) return;//é˜²æ­¢ç»§ç»­å¾ªç¯è¦†ç›–æ‰æ­£ç¡®ç­”æ¡ˆ } } } bool IsEulerRoad() { int Count = 0; int In = 0, Out = 0; for(int i = 0; i < 26; ++i) { if(OutDegree[i] != InDegree[i]) { ++Count; if(OutDegree[i] > InDegree[i]) { Out = OutDegree[i] - InDegree[i]; Begin = Ptr[i];//å‡ºåº¦å¤§çš„ç‚¹åº”è¯¥ä¸ºèµ·ç‚¹ã€‚å‡å¦‚è¿™å¥æ²¡æœ‰æ‰§è¡Œï¼Œè¯´æ˜è¿™å¼ å›¾å¯èƒ½æ˜¯æ¬§æ‹‰å›¾ï¼ŒBegin=0ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ­£ç¡®çš„; } else { In = InDegree[i] - OutDegree[i]; } } } if(!Count) return true; if(Count != 2) return false; return ((Out == 1)&&(In == 1)); }

posts.title: ç¬¬äºŒç±»Stirlingæ•°
posts.text: ç¬¬äºŒç±»Stirlingæ•°å®é™…ä¸Šæ˜¯é›†åˆçš„ä¸€ä¸ªæ‹†åˆ†ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºå°†nä¸ªä¸åŒçš„å…ƒç´ æ‹†åˆ†æˆmä¸ªé›†åˆçš„æ–¹æ¡ˆæ•°ï¼Œæœ¬æ–‡å°†å…¶è®°ä¸ºS(n,m)={n\brace m} æ±‚è§£S(n,m)çš„é—®é¢˜å¯ä»¥ç­‰ä»·ä¸ºè§£å†³ä»¥ä¸‹é—®é¢˜ï¼šå°†nä¸ªä¸åŒçš„çƒæ”¾å…¥mä¸ªæ— å·®åˆ«çš„ç›’å­ä¸­ï¼Œè¦æ±‚ç›’å­éç©ºï¼Œæœ‰å‡ ç§æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Ÿ å®¹æ˜“å¾—åˆ°ä»¥ä¸‹å¼å­ï¼š1ã€{n \brace 0}=02ã€{n \brace 1}=13ã€{n \brace n} = 14ã€{n \brace 2}= 2^{n-1} - 15ã€{n \brace n-1}= C _n^2 è¿™äº”ä¸ªå¼å­ä¸è¶³ä»¥æ±‚è§£ï¼Œè¿˜éœ€è¦ä¸‹é¢çš„é€’æ¨å…¬å¼ï¼š{n\brace r} = r {n-1 \brace r} + {n-1\brace r-1} å¦‚ä½•ç†è§£è¿™ä¸ªå…¬å¼å‘¢ï¼Ÿ 1ã€æˆ‘ä»¬å…ˆå°†nä¸ªçƒéšæœºæ ‡è®°ä¸º1ã€2ã€3â€¦nã€‚ 2ã€å…ˆå°†å‰n-1ä¸ªçƒæ”¾å…¥rä¸ªç›’å­ã€‚æ”¾ç½®å®Œæˆåæœ‰ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µï¼šâ‘ æ¯ä¸ªç›’å­éƒ½æœ‰çƒ{n-1\brace r}â‘¡åªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªç›’å­æ²¡æœ‰çƒã€‚{n-1\brace r-1} 3ã€å†æ”¾ç¬¬nä¸ªçƒâ‘ æ¯ä¸ªç›’å­å·²ç»æœ‰çƒäº†ï¼Œç”±äºæ¯ä¸ªçƒéƒ½æ˜¯ä¸åŒçš„ï¼Œè¿™rä¸ªç›’å­æ¯ä¸ªéƒ½æ˜¯ç‹¬ä¸€æ— äºŒçš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥éœ€è¦ä¹˜ä»¥rr {n-1 \brace r} â‘¡æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªç©ºç›’ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆç¬¬nä¸ªçƒåªèƒ½æ”¾åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªç©ºç›’é‡Œ ï¼Œä¸éœ€è¦å†ä½œè¿ç®—{n-1\brace r-1}å› æ­¤å¾—å‡ºæœ€åç»“æœ{n\brace r} = r {n-1 \brace r} + {n-1\brace r-1}æˆ‘è§‰å¾—éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„çš„ç‚¹æ˜¯ï¼šç¬¬nä¸ªçƒæ˜¯éšæœºå¾—æ¥çš„ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ä»»ä½•ç‰¹æ®Šæ€§ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å–çƒçš„è¿‡ç¨‹æ˜¯ä¸éœ€è¦è¿ç®—çš„ã€‚ Cè¯­è¨€å®ç°ï¼š long long Stirling2(int n,int m) { if(n < m) return 0; if(!m) return 0; if(m == 1) return 1; if(m == n) return 1; if(m == 2) return (1 << (n - 1)) - 1; if(n == m + 1) return n * m / 2; return m * (Stirling2(n - 1,m)) + Stirling2(n - 1,m - 1); }
